reviewText:
Taking for granted that you played or know Far Cry 3:

Pros:- Himalayas are beautiful and full of different activities.
- Stealth feels a little better. Mainly on outposts.
- Nice optimization (at least for NVIDIA users).
- Wildlife is dangerous and annoying XD (I like that)
- Is not as longer as FC3 but it has very nice missions!
- More guns, memorable side quests, random events and more activities and ways to travel ;) (oh that little helicopter <3)
- Music variety and unknown great artist from other cultures ;) Listen to this :D https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VmHHXNP6uGU
- Of course those weird moments / missions under the influence :P
- The map editor
- The alternative ending ;)

Cons:- I hate seeing AMD people having problems during the first weeks of this kind of games. I'm not AMD user but I find this kind of partnerships don't help (to the whole market at least).
- Weak plot twists (FC3 was too good for me)
- At the beginning some guns are so annoying to accomplish a good long distance shot ¬¬
- The engine works great but it has some popup problems and a few fun glitches haaha!

Far Cry 4 is a worthy sequel. If you didn't play FC3 you SHOULD play both. Doesn't matter the order for me (aside a few little details) ;)  It was good to have a good Ubisoft Montreal game after ACU fiasco. Anyways, I will not rely that much on the U again aside Far Cry.

reviewText: This game is a lot like farcry 3 but with a cooler enviroment, better villian, and less emphasis on machete takedowns and stealth. The open world has more to explore and many more tasks to preform. The co-op is the best ive played this year hands down. My favorite weapons are the bow which is great for silently clearing out outpost (the machete takedowns are far less powerful) and the grenade launcher which causes absolute chaos for your enemies. The vehicle combat is WAAAAY cooler thanks to the new vehicles (particularly the gyrocopter) and the ability to use sidearms while driving (did i mention grenade launchers are a sidearm?) also you can ride elephants. The elephants can crush enemy vehicles and troops like they were made from sand! The wingsuit is accessable earlier in the game which is nice for traversing the mountain terrain, also you can use grappling hooks though only on certain ledges. My only problem is the wildlife, Farcry 3 had wildlife but it wasn't nearly as annoying as its predecessor. Eagles will fly from the sky and attack you for no reason while your trying to clear an outpost, ruining any attempt at stealth and taking a good chunk of health, packs of dogs will follow you for miles and rip you to shreds, fighting them is essentially impossible because they spam attack you so much you cant even let a shot off, the only fun wildlife is the bears and tigers, they dont have major advantages over you other than being fast and deadly, thats what i want from wildlife NOT unfair, random attacks that spam you and cant be blocked (you can't even stop an eagle from attacking you and as stated dogs and wolves wont give you time enough to attack). Over all the game falls flat because of its lack of driving force and annoying wildlife. Still clearing outposts and attacking convoys is more fun than ever before. 8.5/10

reviewText:
This is one of the best games I played in a long time. It has a well written story that makes you feel like your there. The amount of content that this has is ridiculous. ( In a good way) Much more than Far Cry 3. The game is extremely well optimized. Runs as good as Far cry 3 if not better. Much more guns than FC3 as well, all unique.

-The Co-op-

The Co-op includes everything you would image a co-op to have. Separate side missions. Almost flawless compatibility and everything the singleplayer has except the singleplayer campaign. How the co-op works is, you go into the menu and press invite freinds. The uplay overlay will open, and you invite the friend you want. Extremely easy. Whoever is host will have the same progress as they did in the campaign. So the content he/she unlocked in the singleplayer will be transferred over to the co-op, which is a feature I like alot.

-Battles of Kyrat-

This game mode is a 5v5 versus match, with a variety of game modes. You can pick from different maps, and upgrade your charter with the ingame points you get for scoring or getting kills.

-Community Maps-

Commuity maps are the maps other people make with the Far Cry 4 editor. Some can be good, and some not so much. But I had fun with them never the less. Pretty strait forward.

-Map Editor-

The map editor is basically a simpler version of a full game engine. You can't make your own models, or textures (as far as I know) but it still isn't to restricted. You can still make some incredible maps. You have almost all the assets from the full game to use. You can change the water level, add npcs, change the skybox, and the ambient sounds, grass, trees etc.

-Opinions-

So far this game has been amazing. The only really downside is some bugs here and there, but then again it didn't come out to long ago. It's a great game, and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
A really fun game that I recommend everyone should give it a try. The game is an amazing game with great graphics and gameplay.

Bat things about the game:
*The game is the story line is more or less just meh. Has boring characters with unskippable cut-scenes.
*This is one of those games that have little to no replayability. Once the campaign is over, you just have to go around collecting boxes to get that 100%.
*Co-op is dumb. You dont play the campaign co-op, all you can do is liberate the towers, which aint that hard or fun to do together.
*Having to install uplay is not necessary a bad thing, but its an extra step to play with someone online.

That being said, those are really the only bad things about the game. Gameplay is solid and fun. It has its unique characteristics with its own world. I recommend buying it at the current price. The DLC is not really needed, as it mainly just gives you OP weapons (pay to win). So I say the game is worth the $40 is asking atm, but I would wait for it to go on sale again, the sweet spot is at $30 if you can get it at that.

reviewText:
This game was a lot of fun. If you've played Farcry 3 before than it's basically the same game except with a different setting and characters of course.

Story  The overall plot is what exactly what you would expect from a Farcry game. In other words, you're a tourist trapped in a region of war. As the tourist, you have choices to make as you help the rebellion take down the mighty king (antagonist). Overall, same old same old plot. I completed the story after about 20 hours (according to Steam).

Gameplay  Along the way, there's plenty of side stuff for you to do such as take down enemy outposts (you can go guns blazing or try to be stealth about it), do other takedown side missions, use your wingsuit, go hunting, customize your weapons, enjoy the scenery etc.

Sound  Overall, amazing music and sound effects. All the guns sound great.

Graphics  The game looks amazing, see the screenshot below for example.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=698419863

Performance  I have a 3570k @ 4.1Ghz, GTX 780 SC, 16 GB of RAM, @ 1440p and perfomance was better than I expected on Ultra. I was around 50fps average with average minimum being around 40fps.

reviewText:
Not much of a change from Far Cry 3 and that's good and bad.

I personally think Pagan is as strong a villain as Vas was, and that's good and they fix the mistake of it's predecessor by NOT making him a secondary antagonist (why they did that I'll never know, such a waste).  The other villains in the story, while not quite like Buck (good and bad), were very well done.

Differences between Pagan and Vas, spoiler free.  Pagan is much more...sentimental than Vas ever was.  And that's good, it makes him compelling and makes me want to know more about him and why he's  such a fascinting evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Yet there are a few things wrong with him, unlike Vas.  I don't fear him, at all, which is good cause it makes him more Hannibal Lectorish.  But, you know, kinda a let down after the intense fear and rush that is Vas.

What kills the game, story wise, is Amita and Sabal.  I despise them.  They're boring, they make me WORK, I don't feel like a liberator with them I feel like a mercenary stuck between two ♥♥♥♥♥♥ managers.  At least Citra was a compelling option and character for an ending.  And their endings (don't worry I'm spoiler free) are...lame.  It's really bad when I spend the entire  gme thinking, damn I really want something, anything else than what I'm forced to do for this exciting yet forced story.

Personally, the next DLC should be a third option for the game ending (make it worth that season pass price) like Fallout New Vegas No Gods No Masters, or simply ally with Pagan himself.

Gameplay, smoother than 3, but the side quests are SO BORING.  Main story is okay, but god damn I hate the side quests.  So tedious, uninteresting, and LONG.   Cept the fashion quests and SOME of the Thanka quests (not all because again BORING), play the game to see why, that was some excellent level designing.

One other major complaint, other than weapons, LOOT IS LAME.  Unless you're upgrading your gear or trying to get a specific weapon, there's really no incentive for side quests.

That would be one thing to compliment, as usual, some of the best level designing I've seen in a game.  Love the weapons, love the vertibird, and the environment is perfect.  I could spend days being a primal hunter (ahhhh get it?)

I will say this, for ubisoft, for a PC port, not bad.  No major problems and very few crashes.  That being said, it's pretty bad I have to say that about a Triple A game producer.  Yeah I remember Assassin's Creed Unity, and while I think Assassin's Creed is boring and haven't played a single one past three I WILL NEVER LET YOU LIVE IT DOWN.

All in all....hard to quantify this result but would definitely give it a 7.7/10.  Pretty good game, could be better, but worth a play through.  Work on day story tho.

reviewText:
I LOVE this game. People say it is too much like Far Cry 3, but I say Far Cry 3 was a great game, but Far cry 4 is an AWESOME game. It literally improves every aspect of the game. They might not be changed, but they're definitely  improved. For instance, the general UI/HUD/Menus are all way better; swapping weapons is smoother, controls are better, menus are cleaner. The graphics/atmosphere are waaay better. The shading of this game is, in practice, much better, and the color scheme is infinitely more appealing than the straight greens/blues of Far Cry 3. In this one you'll see every color, and none feel out of place. The whole world is vibrant and so beautiful, in a way not many games can claim to be. The only one I've seen challenge this level of atmospere and world beauty is The Witcher 3, which is one of my favorite games of all time.

Also important, are the additional tools of this game. Not all are necessary, but...this game is meant to be fun, not practical. If you want practical, play Far Cry 2. I think its a blast to charge an elephant through an enemy base, or to fly a helicopter into an enourmous fortress, or to stealth through a level using my throwing knives.

The game just feels better in every way, it's things you notice only when you go back to play 3. Like how you can't shoot out of cars in 3, or how you can't move dead bodies. Or ride a ♥♥♥♥ing elephant. But when you notice them it's hard to enjoy 3 as much. Because Far Cry 3 was a good game, but this is a really good game.

reviewText:
this was good fun, but it has its drawbacks.  it's a ubisoft title, which means (like other ubisoft titles around this release) you'll be doing a lot of climbing towers to unveil parts of the map, finding lots of collectibles, and raiding strongholds of your enemy.  i'm not certain this is a bad thing, since the formula seems to work and it's fairly fun and easy to play, but it's not a totally original experience if you're searching for that. :)

the game will lead you through a decently interesting story to what i felt to be a satisfying enough conclusion.  a few hours into the game, the world map size will effectively double, and the new area will be full of more difficult enemies.  i found this to be a nice but somewhat anticipated surprise.  exploring the map was fun during my downtime, just walking around and finding things to climb up and find collectibles and secret areas.  there are some very pretty vistas in this game.

the wingsuit was a blast, when you find the right tall mountain to jump off of to go to your next destination.  i would often find myself fast-travelling to a tall place instead of a nearby place, just to fly part of the way there.

the vehicle takedowns are nice and smooth.  the auto-drive option is also very nice if you're doing a lot of back and forth. you can appreciate the scenery or take a drink while you're en route to your destination if you'd like.

the co-op, while implemented and certainly entertaining with a friend, i did not find to be particularlly complete.  you cannot do story missions while in co-op, you can only raid strongholds that you have not done before.  you cannot redo strongholds you've already done in either your singleplayer or multiplayer game without resetting all the strongholds permanently.  you can find collectibles and climb map discovery towers as well, so there's plenty to do, but once you run out of stuff there's not much more to go on in co-op.

i would have really liked the ability to go on story missions with a friend and both advance our game together.  even if this seems to break the narrative of a single man changing the country, i think i could live with that in exchange for doing it with a friend.

reviewText:
Far cry 4, the best out of the far cry games. If they make another one it will be very hard to top this.

If you thought far cry 3 was good far cry 4 fixes everything wrong about it AND does everything better. Pagan Min, the best Antagonist/Protagonist(depends on how you view him) I have ever seen, even better than Vaas. The enemies range from kamikazeing into you to strategically drawing you out of cover with a grenade, still not that many enemy types though. Shooting while driving is a new thing, except its hard if you don't have auto-aim on and you can only use side arm weapons like pistols. Lots and lots different of side missions to do if you finished the campaign. Karma is new for it give you discounts and unlocks weapons and skills. Map size is pretty dam big and driving has become smoother than far cry 3 (but sometimes I can't stand the radio guy). Flyable helicopters, throwing knifes and grappling are new. Super amazing graphics(what a time we live in!)

When you skin animals you get bait which you can throw to attract predators to kill enemies. But there are also a new enemy called hunters that can only be tagged for three seconds and can charm predators to attack you, plus there is a whole new strategy for taking camps because the harder ones now have, mortars, machine guns, heavys, snipers, hunters and pyros.

There are large amounts of weapons to unlock, with some of them being even more ridiculously over powered then if far cry 3.The choices in the game are a great new feature, for you have to decide between two people both of which have major faults.

The plot is a bit weird because you come to deliver your mom's ashes to this place and to get there you turn into a mass murdering, animal slaying warrior that everyone solely depends on.

Pagan Min's character and personality is some of the most intricate design I'v ever seen, and I would say he is one of the best character's in video games. Him plus some of my favourite weapons like the grenade launcher, crossbow and the machine pistol makes this a hard game to top for me (now if only they had some more melee weapon, like a katana) 9/10

reviewText: Yet another buggy Ubisoft game, the amount of glitches I've encountered is substantial. Not only do the inability to heal bugs plague multiplayer, in single player vehicle missions are extremely difficult to complete because half of the time they bug out. I've had cars fly in mid air and when I got out the game crashed. It's also possible to drive vehicles into safe areas (cities) only to have the car freeze and become permanently immobile. This is only scratching the surface when it comes to the amount of bugs I've encountered. I'm waiting on a patch before I ever go back to multiplayer.\n\nAnother issue with the game is its illusion of choice ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and its anticlimatic villain. When it comes to selecting a side to fight for, you don't even know what decision to make as both seem reasonable. Only after the mission do you get to hear the other side's reasons as to why you're a terrible person for making the decision. When it comes to the main villain, let's just say he kills people that you couldn't possibly care enough about. Pagan definitely didn't have enough character development and the final confrontation felt rushed.

reviewText:
I have been a loyal customer of yours for many years. Most games, even small indie productions, have worked flawlessly. When bugs or crashes have occured they have been few and far between.
After having played Far Cry 4 for exactly 9.5 hours I can honestly say I have never been this disappointed in a game I bought from you. Even though the game seems to be on par with Far Cry 3 in production quality it is completely unplayable. Black screens, grey screens and random crashes during the most trivial gameplay occur constantly. I waited for the patch that was released today with great expectations but it did nothing to solve the crashes. 12 minutes after starting the game today it crashes to the desktop.
There is nothing to blame in terms of hardware. All other games from you work without a glitch. All software, Adobe CC 2014, AutoCad and multimedia perform without any errors. My system is rock-solid, running Prime95, Intel Burn Test and PCMark 8 concurrently for hours without a hint of problem. No overclocking, no problem with heat.
I do not recommend buying this game at all, instead buy FC3.

reviewText:
The game is pretty entertaining to play. The open world shooter platform is fun, the vehicles in the game are pretty interesting (other than they all go the exact same speed), and the grappling hook in a mountanious terrain makes running around and exploring worthwhile. The weapons and the customizations with them are also entertaining, but the skills leave a lot to be desired (I ended up having stacks of 10 skill points saved up because I couldn't spend them due to some skills requiring mission unlocks).

The characters in the game are for the most part good, but there's also some dialog scenes and character development that have their WTF moments. I would say in all the missions were relatively entertaining, albeit very adult in nature. The in-game currency is also valuable as you use it to buy weapons / ammo, and it is possible to run out of it, but not likely.

With all that said, lets get to the bugs / oversights in the game (and I'm sure I'm missing a lot too).

First, you can't easily switch weapons after starting a mission. So if your mission requires that you need a rocket launcher to take out a vehicle, there's no real way to get one other than trekking back to an outpost to switch weapons to a rocket launcher, which isn't fun at all, or sometimes impossible if you die and you are at a checkpoint which wont allow you to go back.

Second, the keybinds don't make sense for someone with keyboard and mouse. Like, you can press and hold Q, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 and bring up the weapon select popup window, but you can't bind individual weapons or slots to any of those keys... makes no sense. The game was designed with a controller in mind, but they could have put in the extra 2 hours of thought to do it better. I could be wrong on this, but if it is possible, it's not intuitive at all.

Third, I'm going to go into a lot of multiplayer issues, and this section is pretty long. To start, how the hell do you make a multiplayer game that has no chat. I know there's a voice chat feature, but I've never been able to get it to work. I've only had one guy talk to me in game, and even though my binds are correct and my mic works, I couldn't talk back to him. If this one feature worked correctly, or if there was text chat, the game would be infinitely more enjoyable. It sucks when you're playing with someone and you can't discuss tactics to conquer an outpost of complete a mission. Huge oversight / mistake. This makes the game quite frustrating in practice. Next up, lets talk about the FOV when riding as a passenger in a vehicle. I don't know if this bug is due to me having the FOV cranked up to the highest setting, but whenever I ride as a passenger in a vehicle, unless I am zooming/scoping a gun from the passenger seat, my FOV changes to something like 180, and it looks like I'm viewing the game through an extreme fisheye lens. This makes me pretty nauseas when it happens, and vehicle travel is essential in the game. This leads to another common problem... half the time in multiplayer, my keybinds wont work... example: I can't enter a vehicle, there's no little popup to let me get in the vehicle, and if I press the key to normally get in a vehicle, I can't get in it. I have to completely restart the game to fix this sometimes, and with the way the game is setup, you can't just start playing with the same person again, it's off to search for another partner in matchmaking and hope it doesn't happen again. This bug happens about 50% of the time I play coop, which is stupid. It's not limited to entering vehicles... I've had my camera key stop working, the key to switch weapons stop working, almost every every in-game bind stop working except for maybe WASD, thats about it. Hugely disappointing. Then there's the ammo bug, where you'll enter a game with full ammo in multiplayer, and then have a fraction of that ammo available. So you go and refill your ammo (which is quite expensive), and then have the same thing happen again the next game. I realized after paying a ton of money to refill my ammo and saying forget it, that if I waited for a long enough time in game, my ammo would magically appear. Pretty frustrating to say the least.

In conclusion, I'd say the game was probably not worth the money. The bugs / game oversights I mentioned above really turned me from someone who liked the concept of the game into someone who isn't a huge fan of the devs / ubisoft for what they left out. Just the lack of multiplayer chat is a gameplay dealbreaker, and tie that in with the bugs I listed and the ones I forgot about, and you get a half-baked game release. I'd say still get the game if you like what you've seen in trailers / gameplay, but wait till it goes on sale and hope they fixed the bugs.

reviewText:
This remarkable game has been extensively reviewed elsewhere. The purpose of THIS review is to give me an opportunity to organize my own thoughts about it. I have played all Far Cry games on PC (Far Cry and Far Cry 2, multiple times. And don’t forget the awesome Far Cry: Blood Dragon). Far Cry 4 is very similar in concept to Far Cry 3 – both very large open world games in which the protagonist, (unskilled, inexperienced, unequipped) struggles against the brutal tyranny of a charming psychopath. Although I enjoyed Far Cry 3 from beginning to end, Far Cry 4 got off to a very rocky start for me. But first the good stuff.

The implementation of stealth is very well done in this game. I say this after just finishing Crysis 3 in which there was no stealth. In Crysis 3, if you weren’t cloaked while crouched and peeking around a corner, you would be instantly fired upon by soldiers or aliens a half mile away. Ridiculous! Not so in Far Cry 4. And you really need to be stealthy in Far Cry 4. The good news is that stealthy behavior pays off a lot. Don’t need no freaking nano suit.

Elephants. One of the most fun elements of the game, riding elephants. You have to pay for this as a skill. So, work up to it. Elephants are a very safe and practical way to move across the map. Encounter an enemy patrol, no problem. Run the elephant into them and melee with the elephant’s trunk. You can destroy oncoming enemy vehicles head on. Loads of fun. Elephants also provide great protection against the multitudes of predators that menace the landscape. And even while dismounted, nearby elephants act on your behalf with close encounters involving harassments by enemies.

Shangri-La missions. Although the main story is fine, I especially enjoyed the five missions to Shangri-La. I hadn’t read about the game beforehand and I was very surprised by these missions. I especially appreciated the expose’ and enactment of the battle to wrest control over Shangri-La from the forces of evil. I was joined by a svelte ally for most of the missions. Arena style battles here and very, very challenging. Yet beautiful and enchanting.

Ghale Homstead. Reminded me of the Hearthfire DLC in Skyrim. You need to find this location, and it takes some doing to get there. Once established, you can pay for upgrades. One of the best upgrades is the option to purchase a buzzer – little gyrocopter. Buzzers are awesome ways to travel and scout out unexplored territory, but they are hard to find as just random drops. But once you own one, just fast travel to the Ghale homestead and climb in.

DJ Rabi Ray Rana. I really enjoyed the mindless chatter coming out of the radios. I know some players hated this guy, but I loved him. He injected some interesting and positive energy in what was otherwise a dreary and hopeless existence. Most of all, I loved the music that accompanied his show. I am still looking for a playlist of his music.

Weapons. As always, there are amazing weapons choices, but (as always) you have to build up to them. My favorite sidearm was the Auto-Cross. This is an automatic mini-crossbow. It is a silent one-shot killer and it is indispensable in the times before acquiring a silenced sniper rifle. I loved this thing and I never stopped carrying it. Still carried my bow, but for long-distance silent kills, the Auto-Cross excelled.

Grappling hook. It was awesome. Easy to use (after some practice). Never glitched.

Lore. The game takes place in Kyrat, a fictional country nestled between India and the Himalayan Mountains. The game’s setting is filled with ancient lore and beautiful traditional art from the region – paintings, statues of hindu deities, and shrines. The value and importance of the region’s beliefs and heritage becomes a critical consideration later in the game. I chose to preserve it.

Ethnic origins. It was pretty obvious that the Adherents and soldiers of the Golden Path were of Indian (or thereabouts) descent and the Royal Army was of Chinese origin. Accents and even expressions in native tongues revealed this difference. Somewhat mirroring the ongoing struggle in Nepal between natives of Tibet and Chinese from the north.

Noore’s Arena. Meh. Hunger Games style battles with supporters tossing in resources for you. The public address commentary is sensational and perfectly captures the depraved sentiment of the event. But after a few rounds, the arena becomes a grind to unlock weapons. You make a little money but not much. In order to unlock the much coveted Bushman silenced assault rifle, you need to achieve level 10 in the arena. I chose not to. It would be hours of formulaic running, gunning and healing. Not for me.

Now, some of the problems I had with the game. Let’s start with the main quest. In a word, fragmented. On reflection after finishing the game, the main quest seemed uncohesive, not pulled together. It kinda just went… “wherever.” For example, it seemed that after completing a main quest challenge, then afterwards for a time, there was nothing. No more challenges, no place to go. I suppose this “down time” might have been intended to give me a chance to explore the vast map, but I just felt a little too much set adrift. Then suddenly a new main quest challenge would pop up on the map. I eventually got used to this and it was fine. But overall, the story and action did not naturally cohere. It’s like reading a book and finishing a chapter. Then turn the page and there’s nothing but a blank page and several more after that. Then after a few more blank pages, you discover the next chapter.

Here is an example. As you might expect, there was the obligatory betrayal and imprisonment episode. Not surprising. But after the escape (which was a big ordeal and a really hard challenge), there was nothing. No response or comment by the antagonist. No, “I’ll get you for escaping my prison!” One day I was in his prison. The next I was out. And life just went on as if it had never happened. Lame.

Flying and falling glitches. One of the iconic activities of Far Cry games are the hang gliders. But I was conditioned to stop using them in Far Cry 4. Often I would just die immediately after deployment. I mean instantly. No collision, just falling and death. Wingsuit too. Jump off a cliff and hit the control to deploy the wingsuit (Shift key in my case) and nothing. No wingsuit just falling and death. The only device that worked reliably was the parachute. They really screwed up this joyful mechanic in this game.

Dogs. In some regions, the landscape is “hounded” by packs and packs of wild dogs. To the extent that it becomes boorish. Each pack has four or five and each dog takes nearly a full clip from an assault rifle to kill. There is just no way to walk terrain in these areas. Always need a jeep or an elephant. Which sucked because I prefer to walk most of the time. Thankfully, most regions don’t have dogs but they were present in enough places to give me a sad. In the S.T.A.L.K.E.R, games there were dogs too, but one headshot would kill them, and THEY were mutated super dogs. So, the implementation of wild dogs in Far Cry 4 was dumb.

Overall and despite some minor complaints, Far Cry 4 matched and in some cases exceeded its predecessors. The landscape is the most beautiful I can remember playing on. The bot AI was masterful. The choices I have as a player are enormous. Stealth, grappling hook, Auto Cross, elephants, buzzer, Shangri-La and I almost forgot, Yogi and Reggie help make this game very worthwhile.

reviewText: Far Cry is back and I couldn't be any more happy with how it's turned out, it brings everything you liked about Far Cry 3 and refines itself with a new environment and new characters. As the saying goes if it's not broken don't fix it."\n\nNow there's plenty to like about this game I mean for one it's set in a fictional Himalayan country a cross between Nepal and India
date: it screams culture. The story is great with the awesome new addition of making choices it's light but still works
recommended: playing solo missions took about 16-18 hours. There's also coop free roam and side quests which take up a whole lot of time as well
hoursPlayed: it's hard to say how long it takes but I have spent more than 10 hours messing about with friends
voteText: so the length of the game is more than good. There's tonnes of user and graphics options to mess with which is really good to see
helpfulPercent: the keyboard and mouse work perfect fully rebindable and so does a controller but that only has presets. There's a bunch of the good old stuff to see here too like hunting
votesHelpful: crafting
votesTotal: weapon customization etc with a few new things to see here and there
votesFunny: some of the new things to note down are choppers
commentsCount: grappling hooks etc. The soundtrack is awesome and so are the sound effects for everything else. The voice acting is great too my favorite is Sabel voiced by "Naveen Andrews" from the show Lost. They nailed the navigation down it's simple and easy to follow and they even added an auto drive feature for cars. Lastly the map is huge there's just so much going on
column16: different zones for different things there's even cool little instances to go to the Himalayas and stuff like that.\n\nA few bad things I didn't like though was firstly the game starts of it's cinematics in full screen then right after the prologue chucks all of them into a black bordered mode small gripe which annoyed me. I really liked the new villain Pagan Min he wasn't Vaas but he was still damn good
column17: it's just a shame he doesn't show up much at all in the game... Now with all the options this game has it was a little odd to see that the game only has a master slider for volume which is fine but it would have been nice to have more options.\n\nIt's not the perfect game and I can't blame it
column18: after all it did come out after Far Cry 3 and that would be hard to beat. If you just want something more after Far Cry 3 then this game is right up your alley it scratches that itch and gives you everything you'd want from a Far Cry game."

reviewText: Far Cry C4 is fantastic and yes I said C4, because explosions are great. They are probably what makes this game pop and what makes battles/skirmishes so fantastic. The graphics and textures are amazing on all settings, and just like explosions color settings make this game truly an artistic masterpiece. The gameplay does have quite a similar likeness to the previous game. But it looks and feels different. The weaponry is very bold and even looks, sounds, and feels good. The missions are very unique and are not even remotely similar to others. The characters are very real and each have a personality of their own. (Except for the usual infantry/rebels)  I also absolutely love the new addon's in FC4, such as the special weaponry, mini heli, riding elephants, etc. Overall this game gets a 8.6/10and is easily worth the $49.99

reviewText:
If you want, you can first see my review of far cry 1. it's always about the first game in it's franchise for me personally.

The focus of this game in it's production was set on HIGH VISUAL GRAPHICS, and bringing a massive big scale universe to life in FIRST PERSON, and it so does that, in fact it does it so right !!!

But the hero of the game and the story is such an unattractive unlikely character that is not a warrior and is a loser who cant even pull up his nose when he catches a cold...!!!
And that really effects the game and bring harm to it

This game has it's issues but it does sooooo manyyyyyy things right that you can forgive a few bad decisions about it.

As far as the industry has developed you can get the best psychedelic missions in this game in yugie and reggie missions which r SO AMAZINGGGGGGGGGGGG !

The shangri la missions are intresting, the final battle in game (taking pagan's fortress) is really easy but instead the last shangri la mission BOSS is So haaard and so fuuuuun

The YUMA boss battle is not at all good and its not related to the cinematics before and after it...
A good example of a boss battle like yuma done right is the boss in DEVIL MAY CRY 3 (the woman bat boss ).

I wanted to give this game 8 or maybe 8.5 but the TENSION you get in the last mission before the game ends is so gooooooooood, and it's done so right.... that :

****i will give this game : 8.6*********

And it's because it gives you the tension of the choice u make so good, this ideology is what drives most bethesda games like fallout and elder scrolls, in far cry this is really the only time u get this in the entire game, but they did it so much better than bethesda in my opinion.....

I recomend you play the yugi regie misions and shangri la and the main story mission...

And the graphics are AWESOME if u have enough vga for it .

****i will give this game : 8.6*********
